text:
The area lies in the Pilbara Region of the Eremaean Province, close to the southern margin of the 
 Fortescue Botanical District [Beard 1990].  Vegetation is dominated by spinifex grasses, Triodia 
 pungens and Triodia wiseana. Scattered acacia grevillea hakea and cassia shrubs dot the area. 
 Broad  shallow  drainages  are  dominated  by  mulga,  Acacia  aneura,  with  scattered  coolabahs, 
 Eucalyptus microtheca, in some areas. Mulgas occupy the south faces of some steeper hills and 
 ridges,  and  are  widespread  on  the  flats  overlying  granite  country.  The  bigger  drainages  are 
 occupied by river gums, Eucalyptus camuldulensis, as well as creek mulga, and in some areas 
 paperbarks, Malaleuca leucadendra, are present. 
 TENEMENT STATUS 
 E52/1908  was  granted  on  10th  August,  2006  and  consists  of  39  sub  blocks.  The 
 expenditure requirements are $39,000 (Figure 2). 
 GEOLOGY  
 The lease straddles the 1:250,000 boundaries of the Newman and Robertson  geological sheets. 
 The area is situated in the Sylvania Inlier, at the southeastern corner of the Pilbara Craton.  The 
 Sylvania Inlier is comprised of typical Archaean granite greenstone terrain, > 2750 Ma.  In the 
 north  and  southwest  it  is  unconformably  overlain  by  rocks  belonging  to  the  late  Archaean  to 
 Early  Proterozoic  Hammersley  Basin.  In  the  west  it  is  unconformably  overlain  by  rocks 
 belonging  to  the  Middle  Proterozoic  Bresnahan  Group,  and  in  the  south  and  east  it  is 
 unconformably overlain by rocks belonging to the Middle to Late Proterozoic Bangemall Basin.  
 The  lease  is  underlain  by  rocks  of  granitoid  origin  transected  by  alluvial  tracts  draining  in  a 
 north-westerly  direction.  The  majority  of  the  inlier  is  underlain  by  granitic  rocks,  which  vary 
 from undeformed to strongly sheared and locally mylonitised granite and granodiorite (Plan 2). 
 These contain a number of greenstone belts of varying size and complexity. They also contain a 
 structurally controlled outlier of Fortescue Group mafic volcanic and felsic sedimentary rocks, 
 which  have  undergone  locally  strong  tectonism  and  hydrothermal  alteration,  located  in  the 
 Round Hill - Capricorn Roadhouse area. 
 Sylvania Uranium Project               Annual Report  E52/1908                2007

14.text: The  drainage  is  ephemeral,  and  no  permanent  water  holes  exist,  although  some  may  last  for

15.text: extended  periods  after  heavy  rains.  Small  quantities  of  potable  underground  water  can  be

16.text: obtained from station bores in the area.

21.text: The largest and most complex of the greenstone belts is the Jimblebar greenstone belt, which is

28.text: 12.5 kilometres wide. It is comprised of intercalated fine to very coarse grained clastic rocks,

29.text: cherts,  banded  iron  formation,  ultramafic  to  felsic  volcanic  rocks,  a  significant  ultramafic  to

30.text: mafic layered intrusion, and the Coobina ultramafic intrusion.

31.text: Several generations of faults have affected the belt. They include early north trending strike slip

32.text: faults,  with  associated  gold  mineralisation  in  the  Shearers  and  Sunny  South  areas,  easterly

35.text: Proterozoic  age.  Late  stage  northeast  striking  sinistral  faults  are  common,  and  occasional

36.text: northwest striking sinistral and dextral faults occur.

37.text: Thrust  faulting  clearly  affects  the  granites  in  places.  A  thick  low  angle  south  to  southwest

38.text: dipping mylonite within a broad zone of sheared granite has been observed near the Sylvania

49.text: gold  discoveries  associated  with  shear  zones  and  altered  mafic  rocks  related  to  banded  iron

54.text: Pancontinental Mining conducted extensive gold exploration in the area from 1980 to 1985.

text:
large scale close to tight overturned fold structures, and localised thrusting; the third period of 
 deformation resulted in open to close steeply plunging folds, crenulation and kinking of s2, and 
 the formation locally of s3.  
 Metamorphism  of  the  greenstones  occurred  under  greenschist  -  facies,  with  both  chlorite  and 
 biotite zones being present. Small pockets of greenstones reached amphibolite facies. 
 The largest and most complex of the greenstone belts is the Jimblebar greenstone belt, which is 
 located  in  the  northeastern  sector  of  the  Sylvania  Inlier,  and  overlain  in  the  north  by  Late 
 Archaean  felsic  volcanic  rocks  belonging  to  the  Fortescue  Group  and  the  Early  Proterozoic 
 Marra  Mamba  Iron  Formation  of  the  Hammersley  Group.  The  magnetic  signature  of  the 
 greenstones  indicates  that  they  continue  north  for  two  kilometres  beneath  Fortescue  and 
 Hammersley  Group  rocks.    The  greenstones  form  a  strongly  arcuate  northerly  to  westerly 
 trending belt with a total length of approximately 25 kilometres, varying from 0.5 kilometres to 
 12.5 kilometres wide. It is comprised of intercalated fine to very coarse grained clastic rocks, 
 cherts,  banded  iron  formation,  ultramafic  to  felsic  volcanic  rocks,  a  significant  ultramafic  to 
 mafic layered intrusion, and the Coobina ultramafic intrusion.   
 Several generations of faults have affected the belt. They include early north trending strike slip 
 faults,  with  associated  gold  mineralisation  in  the  Shearers  and  Sunny  South  areas,  easterly 
 striking southerly dipping reverse and thrust faults, plus a significant easterly striking southerly 
 dipping fault zone, The Cubana fault, with minor associated Pb Ba mineralisation, probably of 
 Proterozoic  age.  Late  stage  northeast  striking  sinistral  faults  are  common,  and  occasional 
 northwest striking sinistral and dextral faults occur.  
 Thrust  faulting  clearly  affects  the  granites  in  places.  A  thick  low  angle  south  to  southwest 
 dipping mylonite within a broad zone of sheared granite has been observed near the Sylvania 
 homestead turn - off from the Great Northern Highway. Its age is not known. 
 The second period of tectonism was related to the early Proterozoic Capricorn Orogeny, and led 
 to  the  formation  of  major  easterly  trending  shear  zones  and  thrust  faults.  Reactivation  of 
 Archaean structures was common. 
 HISTORICAL EXPLORATION 
 Alluvial gold was first discovered in the Jimblebar greenstone belt in 1887. Several hard rock 
 gold  discoveries  associated  with  shear  zones  and  altered  mafic  rocks  related  to  banded  iron 
 formation,  followed.  Scattered  small  gold  workings,  generally  in  shear  zones  in  altered  mafic 
 and  ultramafic  rocks,  occur  elsewhere  in  the  belt.  A  state  battery  was  established  during  the 
 1930s to treat ore from the area. Total recorded production was 107 kilograms of gold. Western 
 Mining Company drilled several diamond drill holes in the Sunny South area in the 1960s, and 
 Pancontinental Mining conducted extensive gold exploration in the area from 1980 to 1985. 
 BHP  Pty  Co  Ltd  and  L  Ives  [1952  and  1957]  produced  14,650  tonnes  of  chromite  from  the 
 Coobina Chromite Deposit. Between 1967 to 1973 BHP also explored the belt for base metals

12.text: ground magnetic anomalies at Copper Knob. No economic intersections were recorded.

17.text: barite fluorite mineralisation, but concluded that the discovery of economic Pb Zn mineralisation

20.text: CSR  Ltd  [1981]  sought  platinum  and  chrome  mineralisation  in  the  layered  ultramafics  in  the

21.text: Coobina area, but did not find any economic concentrations.

23.text: Hancock & Wright Prospecting P/L [1983 - 1985] carried out further chromite exploration in the

24.text: Coobina area, defining some additional resources.

26.text: Billiton Australia [1986 - 1989] explored the western and south central areas of the greenstone

27.text: belt for gold platinum and base metals. They conducted an aeromagnetic - radiometric survey [in

28.text: conjunction with GEOPEKO], stream sediment sampling, soil and rock chip sampling, and some

29.text: costeaning. This work defined a number of gold palladium and base metal drainage anomalies.

30.text: Follow up soil sampling was conducted in the Mindoona area, and resulted in the definition of a

31.text: strong lead zinc anomaly; in addition several areas of anomalous gold palladium and platinum

32.text: were  defined.    They  also  tested  for  alluvial  gold  potential  of  the  south  central  part  of  the

33.text: greenstone belt in a joint venture with Kingsgate Resources in 1988.

35.text: GEOPEKO [1987 - 1993] entered into joint ventures with Billiton and various other parties to

36.text: explore for base metals and gold in the Jimblebar - Cubana - Copper Knob and Mindoona areas.

37.text: They undertook aerial photography, an aeromagnetic - radiometric survey [in conjunction with

39.text: RAB drill holes and 8 RC drill holes into various targets in the Copper Knob - Cubana area, and

40.text: a  deep  diamond  drillhole  beneath  the  Copper  Knob  deposit.  This  hole  did  not  intersect

41.text: significant mineralisation. In 1989 they conducted Sirotem and IP surveys over the Pb - Zn soil

42.text: anomaly defined by Billiton in the Mindoona area. No EM anomalies were defined, but the IP

43.text: defined several zones of high chargeability, one of which corresponded to the main Pb - Zn soil

44.text: anomaly.  Three  RC  drill  holes  were  drilled  to  test  the  east  -  west  trending      south  dipping

45.text: gossanous quartzite chert ridge which lies immediately south of the axis of the IP chargeability

46.text: anomaly and corresponding soil anomaly.  All three holes intersected broad widths of low grade

47.text: Zn mineralisation.  No further work was conducted.

49.text: Anvil Mining NL [1993 -1995], in a joint venture with Navan Mines P/L conducted a stream

50.text: sediment  and  lag  survey  for  gold  mineralisation  in  1994  over  the  Mindoona  area.    They  also

text:
of the Jimblebar greenstone belt. They concentrated mainly on the Copper Knob area, located 
 several  kilometres  east  of,  and  along  strike  from,  E52/1176.    They  defined  a  sub  economic 
 deposit of 500,000 tons of 1.8% Cu and 0.3% Zn to a depth of 122 metres, over a strike length of 
 122 metres, within a low grade mineralised envelope consisting of approximately 120 million 
 Aquitaine Minerals P/L [1977 - 1978] drilled three diamond drill holes into two pulse EM and 
 ground magnetic anomalies at Copper Knob. No economic intersections were recorded. 
 Shell  Minerals  [1974  -  1978]  explored  for  Prairie  Downs  style  Pb-Zn  mineralisation  in  the 
 Mindoona and Cubana areas, associated with the east - west Cubana fault zone. They completed 
 geological  mapping,  IP  and  magnetic  surveys.  They  identified  weak  IP  anomalies,  and  minor 
 barite fluorite mineralisation, but concluded that the discovery of economic Pb Zn mineralisation 
 CSR  Ltd  [1981]  sought  platinum  and  chrome  mineralisation  in  the  layered  ultramafics  in  the 
 Coobina area, but did not find any economic concentrations. 
 Hancock & Wright Prospecting P/L [1983 - 1985] carried out further chromite exploration in the 
 Coobina area, defining some additional resources. 
 Billiton Australia [1986 - 1989] explored the western and south central areas of the greenstone 
 belt for gold platinum and base metals. They conducted an aeromagnetic - radiometric survey [in 
 conjunction with GEOPEKO], stream sediment sampling, soil and rock chip sampling, and some 
 costeaning. This work defined a number of gold palladium and base metal drainage anomalies. 
 Follow up soil sampling was conducted in the Mindoona area, and resulted in the definition of a 
 strong lead zinc anomaly; in addition several areas of anomalous gold palladium and platinum 
 were  defined.    They  also  tested  for  alluvial  gold  potential  of  the  south  central  part  of  the 
 greenstone belt in a joint venture with Kingsgate Resources in 1988. 
 GEOPEKO [1987 - 1993] entered into joint ventures with Billiton and various other parties to 
 explore for base metals and gold in the Jimblebar - Cubana - Copper Knob and Mindoona areas. 
 They undertook aerial photography, an aeromagnetic - radiometric survey [in conjunction with 
 Billiton],  stream  sediment  sampling,  soil  sampling,  and  geological  mapping.  They  drilled  179 
 RAB drill holes and 8 RC drill holes into various targets in the Copper Knob - Cubana area, and 
 a  deep  diamond  drillhole  beneath  the  Copper  Knob  deposit.  This  hole  did  not  intersect 
 significant mineralisation. In 1989 they conducted Sirotem and IP surveys over the Pb - Zn soil 
 anomaly defined by Billiton in the Mindoona area. No EM anomalies were defined, but the IP 
 defined several zones of high chargeability, one of which corresponded to the main Pb - Zn soil 
 anomaly.  Three  RC  drill  holes  were  drilled  to  test  the  east  -  west  trending      south  dipping 
 gossanous quartzite chert ridge which lies immediately south of the axis of the IP chargeability 
 anomaly and corresponding soil anomaly.  All three holes intersected broad widths of low grade 
 Zn mineralisation.  No further work was conducted. 
 Anvil Mining NL [1993 -1995], in a joint venture with Navan Mines P/L conducted a stream 
 sediment  and  lag  survey  for  gold  mineralisation  in  1994  over  the  Mindoona  area.    They  also

10.text: Hampton commissioned a 200 metre line spaced magnetic and radiometric survey over the entire

11.text: Sylvania Dome flown during 1997. A review of the radiometric data (Plan 5) and magnetic data

12.text: (Plan 4) identified several anomalies coincident with drainage systems that were prospective for

13.text: calcrete  hosted  uranium  deposits.  A  ground  inspection  was  completed  by  a  consultant  taking

14.text: scintillometer  readings  and  surface  samples  over  the  radiometric  anomalies.  The  report  is

20.text: RAB  drilling  is  planned  to  test  radiometric  anomalies  beneath  alluvium  within  the

text:
WORK COMPLETED  
 Hampton commissioned a 200 metre line spaced magnetic and radiometric survey over the entire 
 Sylvania Dome flown during 1997. A review of the radiometric data (Plan 5) and magnetic data 
 (Plan 4) identified several anomalies coincident with drainage systems that were prospective for 
 calcrete  hosted  uranium  deposits.  A  ground  inspection  was  completed  by  a  consultant  taking 
 scintillometer  readings  and  surface  samples  over  the  radiometric  anomalies.  The  report  is 
 attached as appendix 1. 
 CONCLUSIONS  
 RAB  drilling  is  planned  to  test  radiometric  anomalies  beneath  alluvium  within  the 
 channelised environment.
